body:
That's not quite right.  The reason for the 4th variable is a place holder for resources used by the executor in case it used resources from the frameworkRole (instead of the default role).  This needs to be fixed in TaskUtils.getScalarResources.  Otherwise, Myriad can over subscribe the frameworkRole resulting in TASK_ERROR.  

I've got a pretty good idea how to fix this, but if you'd like to continue working it I'm OK with that.  Wouldn't hurt for a second pair of eyes on that.
@DarinJ Is this something you'd like to get fixed before RC1 ? I'd like to either wait or prepare RC1 based on that.

Thanks @zyluo . 

Ship it :rocket:
@smarella @yufeldman I've got just finished a patch, I'll do a PR in 5 minutes if you can look over it.  It's two lines :).
Thanks @zyluo . Ship it! :rocket:
Ship It! :rocket:

I'll review some more in the mean time.

Will merge this in and cut a RC.
LGTM!! Thanks for making the change.

Commit looks good.  Might want to be consistent and update org.apache.myriad.scheduler.fgs.YarnNodeCapacityManager.java so we get prepended names for FGS as well.  May need to adjust the executor accordingly in the process.
LGTM
LGTM

My concern is mesos-dns, which will already have framework name in the dns A record created.  so this will be <framework-name>.<framework-name>-task-<taskId>.  It also seems like the string "task-" is not useful.

I'm not sure it matters from a mesos-dns perspective here as this is only the nodemanager code, which I've not seen a use-case for mesos-dns hostnames and I don't see an issue with populating some uninteresting hostnames?  Am I missing something?

For services it's set on line 129 of [ServiceTaskFactoryImpl.java](https://github.com/apache/incubator-myriad/blob/master/myriad-scheduler/src/main/java/org/apache/myriad/scheduler/ServiceTaskFactoryImpl.java#L129) so we could still set that to history.myriadframework1.mesos.

Agree task is unnecessary.
@DarinJ I'm in agreement.   lets remove the "task-".

'task-' has now been removed. New Syntax is: 
framworkname-taskId
@mohitsoni @bgulla @DarinJ looking for a thumbs up and I'll merge (or feel free to)
@nmani are we ready for this to be merge?
meaning has it been tested
LGTM
LGTM

@smarella @sdaingade @yufeldman This is WIP but I'm pretty sure it's the right way to correct it.  I'll be cleaning up the code over the next day or two, but if you could take a look before the sync Wed we can discuss.

LGTM will test a clean build if it checks out I'll merge in the next day or so.
Thanks!

@smarella lets talk more about this... this seems to ruin the value of gradlew.  The point of gradlew and the properties file that is in the `gradle/wrapper` directory is to guarantee that the build always works.  If there is a future breaking change in gradle.  the version of gradle known to work is maintained in the project directory.     Also if there are needed properties like requiring a larger heap size for builds, etc.  that is maintained there as well.   To request others to generate the gradlew is to not have a gradlew and require developers to pre-install gradle (in addition to reducing the confidence of a working build)
I guess this is just from the source tar... which bothers me less
@ruth-mapr were you going to respond to @DarinJ comments?
@ZJaffee  This failed due to not including the import for POST... resolved and merged
Is this a good idea?  Seems like we're adding more config to Myriad maybe we should just throw a runtime exception?
As in assert that the port be the default port as we are going now, where we throw an exception should there be no response at the given default port address?

8088 is yarns default HTTP port and 8090 is the HTTPS port.  If neither are in the yarn-site.xml they'll revert to those. The original check in code was for sanity in case the yarn configuration didn't have those values and returned a null.

Adding additional config here could lead to a conflict between yarn and Myriad's perception of the correct port.

The assert would be do we get a value (not null or empty).
Looks good, but will need to update the scripts/Dockerfiles in the docker directory as well (otherwise those will fail to build).
@ZJaffee looks like something broke in the build here.
@kensipe @smarella @sdaingade Any comments on this, I've tested pretty thoroughly and would like to merge.
@DarinJ - sorry for the delay. Will take a look at this today.
@DarinJ - great work :100:
This is weird, it worked locally and the build server is saying that it cannot find nodejs, I'll dive into this later tonight.

A good question would be how are people currently deploying their myriad servers, if they are using some kind of configuration management tool, this makes live much easier if you want to change the port, as you can just create a template file where you can then override the yarn http port. 

If a person is using everything the way using the default configs from both yarn and myriad, then the config is already set as I had done.

That said if you think its best to go the other way then how would you recommend making such an assertion, is there a yarn endpoint we can call to see if that port is the default, is it even worth making such a request if it has to be done over http.
@ZJaffee I messed up here, and made a typo when I merged #57, feel free to resubmit this PR if you want to continue working on it.
Merged, typo prevented asfgit from closing.  So I'm closing manually.

I've been running this for a few days now, while intermittently forcing nodes into unhealthy states (removing local dirs, changing permissions, etc).  It's clear from the logging it's working as expected, I'll merge tomorrow afternoon if I don't get any additional comments.

two minor comments, otherwise looks good. +1
@yufeldman I think this commit addresses all your concerns.  Thanks for the review, definitely better to initialize the method at startup than mess with synchronization and lazy initialization!

This makes sense to render the port configurable and implement the getter with Optional.of(<supplied value>).or("8088") like I did in the MYRIAD-198 pull request. I think it would also be good to include a plugin for a service discovery tool like mesos-dns or consul.  I especially like the latter in that consul supports the SRV protocol, meaning the dns abstracts away both the IP address and the port.
@bgulla can you give me a quick sanity check on docker scripts.  Wanting to ship today and then hit an RC.
Nice will get this merged in today!

@hokiegeek2 looks like you did you're rebase in such away that I can't tell what you modified vs what was modified since you forked master.  Can you please try again as it's really difficult to see if you introduced any regressions?  You should be able to accomplish this by:

```
git fetch upstream
git checkout <your branch>
git rebase -i upstream/master
```

While you're at it I'd suggest squashing you're commits.

There's a lot of good stuff in this PR!  I just want to make sure we get it merged correctly.
@hokiegeek2 let me know if you need more help with the rebase process.
LGTM.. Should we keep typo (hierachy) in the code or fix it as well?
Yeah, looked into it, will fix tomorrow.
@sarjeet2013 went ahead fixed typo and made sure cgroups work.  Can you verify as well?
@DarinJ, Yes. I was able to fix it locally and NM launched fine w/ cgroups. Thanks for making the change, btw.
LGTM, ship it.
Merged.

@yufeldman @sdaingade I modified a lot of your code in here, if you'd like to take a look.  Still a WIP, but trying to clean up the interface between ResourceEventHandler and TaskFactory so we only loop through resources once.  Fixed a few minor bugs in the commandlines we created as well.

@hokiegeek2 please look at this too.
@yufeldman OK cleaned up sorry about that

Wow that's a lot more test coverage.  There are a few areas of the code you've changed I'm unfamiliar with, so I'd appreciate some more eye's on it.  I'll go ahead and try to verify it doesn't break anything.

@hokiegeek2 have you tried verifying you can build and test against varying versions of hadoop? You can do this with:

```
./gradlew -PhadoopVer=2.7.2 build
```

or

```
./gradlew -PhadoopVer=2.6.3 build
```

etc

Hi Darin,

Okay, built and ran unit tests successfully for the following versions:

2.6.2, 2.6.3, 2.6.4, 2.7.1, and 2.7.2

I deployed to our AWS cluster (Hadoop 2.6.0), did flex-up/down, and executed a handful of Hadoop jobs.

--John
